displayed_text:
[Question]

What is your opinion on internet influencers (e.g., streamers, bloggers, short video creators) increasingly becoming a recognized profession?

answer.text_box: not sure how good a deal that is, doesn't really seem like a real profession. but some people make a lot of money doing this.

displayed_text:
Two summaries of opinions are shown below. Read carefully and answer according to your prior opinion. Both are scrollable.

Summary A

Overall summary of the comments:

  • Overall sentiment: Opinions are diverse, with roughly 45% broadly favorable toward influencers as a legitimate profession, about 35% supportive but conditional or mixed, and around 20% negative or dismissive.

  • Perceived benefits:

  • Seen as a natural evolution of media and marketing that democratizes who can build an audience and earn a living.
  • Offers entrepreneurship, flexible/remote work, and new income streams.
  • Provides entertainment, niche expertise, product reviews/demos, and sometimes timely news or analysis.
  • Can stimulate competition that improves content quality and accuracy.

  • Builds communities and validates creative labor; comparable to other entertainment careers.

  • Main concerns:

  • Oversaturation, inauthenticity, and “fake” personas; grifting and pay-to-promote dynamics.
  • Misinformation and the risk of audiences treating influencers as experts, especially on health/news.
  • Unrealistic expectations for youth; perception of “easy money” despite high luck, volatility, and algorithm dependence.
  • Consumerism/overconsumption and questionable social value relative to traditional professions.

  • Mental health strains on creators and parasocial dynamics with audiences.

  • Conditions for legitimacy and trust:

  • Transparency on ads/sponsorships and clear disclosures.
  • Accountability, ethical standards, and responsible behavior given their influence.
  • Media literacy for audiences; encourage not relying on influencers as a sole news source.
  • Fair creator protections (contracts, unions, safety nets) and diversified income.

  • Framing it as a viable path for a small minority; for most, better as a side gig while pursuing education or a trade.

  • Cultural observations:

  • Influencers are viewed as today’s celebrities or “new media houses,” sometimes replacing TV.
  • Pandemic-era growth accelerated recognition.
  • Some prefer the term “content creator” over “influencer.”

Bottom line: Many see influencer work as a real, entrepreneurial profession that can inform and entertain, but its social value and sustainability depend on authenticity, transparency, and responsible practice—and it is unlikely to be a stable or attainable primary career for most people.

Summary B

The comments reflect a wide range of perspectives on the rise of internet influencers as a recognized profession. Many view it positively, emphasizing the opportunities it provides for creativity, entrepreneurship, and accessibility to global audiences. Commenters appreciate how influencers can entertain, educate, and connect with people in ways that traditional media often cannot. Some highlight the role of influencers in democratizing fame and allowing everyday individuals to build careers based on passion and talent.

However, a significant portion of the feedback expresses concerns. Critics argue that the profession can promote superficiality, overconsumption, and a distorted view of success—especially for younger audiences. Some feel that the profession lacks authenticity and is driven more by the pursuit of attention and profit than by genuine value. Others worry about the oversaturation of the market, the pressure to conform to trends, and the potential for misinformation when influencers become primary sources of news and opinion.

There is also a recurring theme around the need for accountability and regulation. Many commenters believe influencers should be transparent about sponsored content, responsible for the impact of their words and actions, and held to professional standards similar to other careers.

While some see influencers as a natural evolution of media and entertainment, others view the phenomenon as a troubling shift in societal values and attention dynamics. Overall, the discussion reflects a nuanced and often polarized view of internet influencers, acknowledging both their potential and their pitfalls.

Below is a summary of people's opinions on the issue.

Overall summary of the comments:

  • Overall sentiment: Opinions are diverse, with roughly 45% broadly favorable toward influencers as a legitimate profession, about 35% supportive but conditional or mixed, and around 20% negative or dismissive.

  • Perceived benefits:

  • Seen as a natural evolution of media and marketing that democratizes who can build an audience and earn a living.
  • Offers entrepreneurship, flexible/remote work, and new income streams.
  • Provides entertainment, niche expertise, product reviews/demos, and sometimes timely news or analysis.
  • Can stimulate competition that improves content quality and accuracy.

  • Builds communities and validates creative labor; comparable to other entertainment careers.

  • Main concerns:

  • Oversaturation, inauthenticity, and “fake” personas; grifting and pay-to-promote dynamics.
  • Misinformation and the risk of audiences treating influencers as experts, especially on health/news.
  • Unrealistic expectations for youth; perception of “easy money” despite high luck, volatility, and algorithm dependence.
  • Consumerism/overconsumption and questionable social value relative to traditional professions.

  • Mental health strains on creators and parasocial dynamics with audiences.

  • Conditions for legitimacy and trust:

  • Transparency on ads/sponsorships and clear disclosures.
  • Accountability, ethical standards, and responsible behavior given their influence.
  • Media literacy for audiences; encourage not relying on influencers as a sole news source.
  • Fair creator protections (contracts, unions, safety nets) and diversified income.

  • Framing it as a viable path for a small minority; for most, better as a side gig while pursuing education or a trade.

  • Cultural observations:

  • Influencers are viewed as today’s celebrities or “new media houses,” sometimes replacing TV.
  • Pandemic-era growth accelerated recognition.
  • Some prefer the term “content creator” over “influencer.”

Bottom line: Many see influencer work as a real, entrepreneurial profession that can inform and entertain, but its social value and sustainability depend on authenticity, transparency, and responsible practice—and it is unlikely to be a stable or attainable primary career for most people.
